headline: Netflix enters exclusive talks to acquire Warner Bros Discovery studio and streaming service, Bloomberg News reporter says
summary: Netflix has entered ‌exclusive talks with Warner Bros Discovery to acquire ⁠its studio ‌and streaming service, a Bloomberg ‍News reporter said in a post ​on X. Netflix has ‌emerged as the top bidder for Warner Bros Discovery, Reuters reported ⁠on Thursday, ​raising the ​stakes in a potential deal that ‍could ⁠reshape the media landscape.

headline: Warner Bros. Is Said to Begin Exclusive Talks With Netflix
summary: Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. has entered exclusive negotiations to sell its film and TV studios and HBO Max streaming service to Netflix Inc., according to people familiar with the discussions. The two companies could announce a deal as soon as in the coming days, assuming talks don't fall apart, the people said. Bloomberg's Manuel Baigorri breaks down the situation.

headline: Is Netflix (NFLX) Undervalued After a 17% Pullback? A Fresh Look at Its Valuation
summary: Netflix (NFLX) has cooled off after a strong run this year, with the stock sliding roughly 17% over the past 3 months even as revenue and profits continue to grow at a healthy clip. See our latest analysis for Netflix. Even after this pullback, Netflix’s 16.4% year to date share price return and powerful three year total shareholder return of 222.6% suggest momentum is cooling rather than collapsing, as investors reassess how much future growth is already priced in. If Netflix’s recent swing...

headline: Warner Bros. Begins Exclusive Deal Talks With Netflix
summary: Netflix is offering a $5 billion breakup fee if regulators don’t approve the deal, said the people, who asked to not be identified because the discussions are private.  The move suggests Netflix has pulled ahead of Paramount Skydance Corp. and Comcast Corp., who were also competing for the asset.  Prior to the closing of the sale, Warner Bros. — valued at more than $60 billion overall — will complete the planned spinoff of cable channels including CNN, TBS and TNT.

Prior to the closing of the sale, Warner Bros. — valued at more than $60 billion overall — will complete the planned spinoff of cable channels including CNN, TBS and TNT.

headline: Netflix agrees blockbuster $72bn deal for Warner Bros studios
summary: Netflix has agreed a $72bn (£54bn) deal to secure Warner Bros Discovery's film and TV studios and supercharge its library through rights to top franchises including Harry Potter and Game of Thrones.  It had been reported that the US streaming giant was in exclusive talks over the deal following a bidding war for the assets.  Paramount Skydance and Comcast, the ultimate owner of Sky News, were the rival suitors.

content.title: Netflix agrees blockbuster $72bn deal for Warner Bros studios
content.summary: Netflix has agreed a $72bn (£54bn) deal to secure Warner Bros Discovery's film and TV studios and supercharge its library through rights to top franchises including Harry Potter and Game of Thrones.  It had been reported that the US streaming giant was in exclusive talks over the deal following a bidding war for the assets.  Paramount Skydance and Comcast, the ultimate owner of Sky News, were the rival suitors.

headline: Netflix in exclusive talks to buy Warner Bros Discovery assets, source says
summary:
STORY: Netflix is reportedly in exclusive talks to buy Warner Bros Discovery's film and television studios, along with its streaming assets.

According to a source with direct knowledge of the matter, it's after offering $28 per share.

The parent of HBO received a second round of bids this week.

Netflix, Paramount Skydance and Comcast had made preliminary buyout proposals.

Reuters previously reported that Netflix was seen as the top bidder, and made a mostly cash offer.

The $28 per share offer compares with Warner Bros' closing price of $24.54 on Thursday (December 4).

And a previous offer from Paramount of nearly $24 for all of the company's assets that also include cable networks like CNN, TNT and TBS.

Netflix and Warner Bros Discovery did not immediately respond to Reuters requests for comment.

Netflix is aggressively diversifying beyond its core subscription model.

A deal with Warner Bros would give it one of Hollywood's most powerful libraries, including "Harry Potter" and "Game of Thrones".

Variety reported the potential deal has led a group of leading film industry figures to urge the U.S. Congress to intervene if Netflix's bid succeeds.

They have apparently warned of a looming economic and institutional crisis in Hollywood.

Paramount has also reportedly accused Warner Bros of running an unfair sale process that favors Netflix over other bidders.

content.title: Netflix in exclusive talks to buy Warner Bros Discovery assets, source says
content.summary:
STORY: Netflix is reportedly in exclusive talks to buy Warner Bros Discovery's film and television studios, along with its streaming assets.

According to a source with direct knowledge of the matter, it's after offering $28 per share.

The parent of HBO received a second round of bids this week.

Netflix, Paramount Skydance and Comcast had made preliminary buyout proposals.

Reuters previously reported that Netflix was seen as the top bidder, and made a mostly cash offer.

The $28 per share offer compares with Warner Bros' closing price of $24.54 on Thursday (December 4).

And a previous offer from Paramount of nearly $24 for all of the company's assets that also include cable networks like CNN, TNT and TBS.

Netflix and Warner Bros Discovery did not immediately respond to Reuters requests for comment.

Netflix is aggressively diversifying beyond its core subscription model.

A deal with Warner Bros would give it one of Hollywood's most powerful libraries, including "Harry Potter" and "Game of Thrones".

Variety reported the potential deal has led a group of leading film industry figures to urge the U.S. Congress to intervene if Netflix's bid succeeds.

They have apparently warned of a looming economic and institutional crisis in Hollywood.

Paramount has also reportedly accused Warner Bros of running an unfair sale process that favors Netflix over other bidders.
